quote: Captain's log, stardate 45944.1.   We're en route to Starbase   Two-eighteen after a magnetic wave   survey of the Parvenium Sector.   We will give our report directly   to Fleet Admiral Gustafson.
The last time I encountered   Admiral Gustafson... I ended up   spending nine straight hours at   the opera.
Nine hours... ?
The entire "Ring" cycle at one   sitting...
That's a little too much Wagner   for me.
And for me... but not, apparently,   for Admiral Gustafson. She went   back the next day and sat through   it all again. I warned her that   this time --
Sir, sensors detect an   unidentified object... twenty-two   thousand kilometers off the port   quarter.
On screen.
Magnify.
Mister Data?
It appears to be a probe of some   kind... but there is no Starfleet   record of this shape or design.
Is it scanning us?
No sir... but it has assumed a   relative position and is holding   course with us.
The probe is composed of...   paricium and talgonite... a   ceramic alloy.
Not a very sophisticated   technology...
Sir, I'm detecting a low-level   nucleonic beam coming from the   probe.
Shields up; stand by phasers.
The beam is scanning the shield's   perimeter.       The probe is emitting an unusual   particle stream --
Captain, the beam is penetrating   our shields --
Increase power to --
Captain?...
Captain, I've got you; it's   all...
Well.. finally.
How are you feeling?
Kamin... can you answer me?
Where is this... ?
You're still feverish...
Computer, freeze program.       End program.
Picard to Enterprise --
Kamin, please don't try to get   up yet... you're still not well.
I asked you... what is this place?
This... is your home, of course.
Where is my uniform? My   communicator?
I'd better call the doctor   again...
I am Captain Jean-Luc Picard of   the Federation Starship   Enterprise. I would like to speak   with whoever is in charge here.
If you'll just lie down, I'll brew   you some nice warm kenomay...
Just tell me this -- am I a   prisoner here?
Please, dear... you've had a high   fever for three days... you   mustn't push yourself too   quickly...
You shouldn't go outside...
Kamin... please come back   inside...
This sapling is planted as an   affirmation of life... in defiance   of the drought and with   expectations of long life.   Whatever comes -- we will keep   it alive, as a symbol of our   survival.
Kamin! You're back on your feet!   How do you feel, my friend?
Are you in charge here?
In charge... ?
I want to be returned to my ship   immediately.
What... ship is that?
Please... if you could tell me...   what is this place? Where am I?
The fever... it's taken your   memory.
That must be it. Perhaps you   could help me...
Anything, my friend.
My name is Kamin... and you are   -- ?
Batai...       Council leader.
Ah. And you say I've been ill...
For over a week. Eline should've   put you in the hospital, but she   insisted on caring for you   herself.
Eline.
Your wife. If you don't remember   that, maybe it's safer not to go   home.
And... what is this place?
Perhaps you should see the   doctor...
Please -- I'm sure it will come   back to me...
This... is the community of   Ressik. Northern province.
What planet?
Come... let me take you back home.
I'm really quite all right. If   you'll just answer...
This is the planet Kataan.
Kataan... not a Federation   planet.
I think I'll take a walk...
You've been ill for a week...
Exercise will do me good. I'd   like to -- re-acquaint myself with   the surroundings.
Thank goodness...
I've had people out trying to find   you everywhere. Why did you   worry us like that?
Are you hungry?
Hungry, thirsty... weary... I   suppose that proves this isn't   a dream, doesn't it?
You think this... your life...   is a dream?
It's not my life... I know that   much.
I've kept something hot for you.
Where did you go?
I walked. For hours.
And you just out of bed...
This is delicious...
You always say that...
Would you -- answer some questions   for me? No matter how strange   they might seem to you?
Of course...
Are there other planets in this   star system? Do you visit any   other systems... ?
All right. Is there any kind of   communication system here? How   do you send messages to... to   other communities? Other places?
The usual way... by   voice-transit conductors. Do   you want to send a message?
Yes. When can that be arranged?
Tomorrow.       Don't you want to ask about...   us?
Of course. Anything you can tell   me would be helpful. We are...   married?

Three years ago... the happiest   day of my life was the day we got   married.       You're probably tired of hearing   it... but I've loved you since   I was seven years old. That's   when I decided I was going to be   your wife, and no one was going   to change my mind.
I'm glad I was so stubborn...
What is it that I do... here in   Ressik?
You're the best iron weaver in   the community. At least I think   so. You prefer playing the flute,   of course.
The flute?
And when did I learn to play it?
I'm afraid you've never learned,   dear. You do keep trying.
I see what you mean.
Thank you for the soup. And for   your help. Tomorrow will you help   me send a message?
Of course. Will you come to bed   now?
I'll sleep here...
Oh, no... please come with me...
I've been sick... I may be tossing   and turning... it wouldn't be fair   to you.
Let me be the judge of that.
Where did you get this?
It's... the first gift you ever   gave me.
... I've got you; it's all right...
Riker to sickbay. The captain's   been hurt.
The nucleonic beam is no longer   scanning, Commander. There is   a narrow reciprocating band   focused directly on Captain   Picard.
Mister Data, find out how that   beam is getting through the   shields and what we can do to cut   it off.
Yes, Commander.
Geordi, start scanning the probe   for any identifying marks,   anything that might tell us where   it came from.
Understood.
Pulse and blood pressure   normal... I'm getting hyperactive   fibrogenic activity... this is   odd...
What is it?
There's no evidence of injury or   trauma... vital signs are normal,   but his neurotransmitter   production is off the scale.   What's going on?
That probe is doing something to   him... Data, any progress?
No, sir. The particle emission   is most unusual. I am unable to   block it.
Destroy the probe. Phasers are   armed and ready.
I don't think that's wise. Not   until we know exactly what it's   doing to him...
Agreed. Stand down phasers,   Mister Worf.
In the meantime, let's see if we   can move out of range. Ensign,   thrusters only... one hundred   kph... nice and easy...
Mister Data?
The probe is moving with us,   sir -- holding relative position.
It's connected itself to him...   like a tether.
You've been dreaming of that   starship again, haven't you?
I'm just charting the sun's   movements. It might give some   clues to the cause of this   drought.
I think you're still trying to   figure out where you are... where   that ship of yours is... what you   can do to get back to that life...
The memory's five years old now,   but it's still inside me.       My other existence may be gone,   but I still wonder about it.
Was it so much better than this   one?
So much more gratifying... so much   more fulfilling... that you cling   to it with such stubbornness?
Eline...
It must have been extraordinary...   but never once, in all the stories   you've told me... have you   mentioned anyone who loved you   as I do.
It was real... as real as this   is. You can't expect me to forget   the lifetime I spent there...
Yes, I can.
I've been patient, Kamin. For   five years I have shared you with   that other life.
I have listened, I have tried to   understand... and I have waited.       When do I get you back?
I know this has been hard for   you...

It's not as though it hasn't been   interesting... all this talk about   starships and distant planets...   I have never been bored.       But I have been lonely. Knowing   that your heart is really...   somewhere else.
You have been amazingly tolerant.
When are you going to let go?   When are you going to start living   this life?       When are we going to start a   family?
Kamin, Eline!
Good morning!
Good morning, Batai...
Are you ready? The administrator   has already arrived.
Yes...       Will you come along?
No, thank you...       ... You do very well on your own.
She always was strong-minded.   Even when she was a child.
It isn't her fault. These last   few years have been difficult for   her.
And for you, I think.
There you are, Batai. Perhaps   you can explain to me... when   crops are dying all over, how this   tree is flourishing?

This tree is our symbol... our   affirmation of life. Everyone   in this town gives a part of their   water rations to keep it alive.       We have learned, Administrator,   that hope is a powerful weapon   against anything... even drought.
A good point. Perhaps I will   recommend a symbolic tree in each   of my communities...       Now. What business do we have   today?
We need help if we're to increase   the water supply. We think there   are ways to reclaim some of our   water...
Batai, you're being a bit of an   alarmist. True, we're in a   drought... but water rationing   has produced a sizeable savings.
If the weather pattern doesn't   change, rationing won't be enough.   We will run out of water.
Who's this?
Kamin, sir.
Kamin... do I know you?
No. I haven't spoken to you   before.
Well, Kamin -- I'm open to all   the people of this town. I'm   delighted to hear what you have   to say. Did you have a specific   proposal?
I suggest we build atmospheric   condensers which could extract   water from the air.
Well. Very ambitious. Kamin,   was it? And your occupation is   -- ?
Iron weaving.       And playing the flute.
I don't mean to quash your very   creative idea... but building   atmospheric condensers would be   a monumental undertaking. We   could not hope to sustain such   a project.
Each community would be   responsible for its own. These   condensers could mean the   difference between watering our   crops... or watching them die.
Well -- I'll be glad to pass   along your suggestion. You'll   see that this kind of   participatory government works   for everyone.
Be well, Batai. I shall see you   next month.       Good to meet you, Kanin.
Go carefully, Administrator...
That went very well. I think he   was impressed with you.
We'll never see an atmospheric   condenser...
These things take time. It will   happen, I'm sure of it.
Come to dinner tonight, my friend.   I'll make a vegetable stew. We'll   talk about building our own   condenser.
Kamin --

Hearing you talk to the   Administrator... I realized that   for the first time in years, you   were speaking as though you were   truly a member of the community.       It was good to hear that again.
You've been brooding behind that   flute all evening.
I'm not brooding. I'm immersed   in my music.
Music...
I've found it helps me think.       The real surprise is that I enjoy   it so much.
The real surprise is that you may   actually be improving.
Batai?
Yes, ma'am.
Go home.
Yes, ma'am.       Goodnight, Kamin.
Goodnight, my friend.
Go carefully, Batai.
Don't forget these. I won't put   them away for you again.
Yes, ma'am.
I've done nothing but nag today.   I'm sorry.
I'm the one who's sorry.       Everything you said this morning   was absolutely right.

I've given you so little... and   you have given me so much...   tenderness, patience... and a good   talking to when I needed it.       You've been more than I could ever   have hoped for. More than I   deserve.
You're a good man, a wonderful   husband... I didn't mean to imply   --
Not such a wonderful husband.

I spend my spare time charting   the stars... I disappear for days   at a time exploring the   countryside... and I never put   away my shoes. I lead my life   very much as I did -- before.       Old habits.
You're gentle and kind... you've   never raised your voice to me...
I'd like to ask your permission   to build something.
Kamin, you've built your   telescope, your laboratory -- you   don't need my permission to build   anything...
In this case, I think I do.
What is it?
A nursery.
Really? Really?
Unless you'd rather have a porch.   It'd certainly be easier to   build...
He's showing heightened activity   in the cerebral cortex...
Pulse and blood pressure are   slightly elevated...
Systemic activity?
Increasing. And I'm getting   heightened tactile responses.
Set up a galvanic scan.
Geordi, any progress identifying   the probe?
Maybe. I've picked up some   residue on the probe's shell.   I think it's from the propulsion   system. Looks like it used a   solid propellant as fuel.
Solid propellant?
Sensors read this stuff as   crystalline emiristol. It   produces a radioactive trail that   ought to be traceable.
Then we can send out a probe of   our own. Trace it back to the   point of origin.
I'll get on it.
Commander, I have been analyzing   the nucleonic beam. I believe   it would be possible to reflect   the particles back toward the   probe in a way that would   disrupt the signal.
Doctor... ?
I don't know what it's doing to   him, or what'll happen if we stop   it...
He could be dying by inches...
His vital signs are stable.   There's no indication he's in a   life-threatening situation --
I'm not willing to let that thing   keep drilling into him --
I simply don't know the risk of   shutting down the beam. If   someone gets stabbed, you don't   necessarily pull the knife out   right away -- that might do more   harm than leaving it there.
The captain is under attack. We   must act.
I'm inclined to agree. Doctor,   monitor him closely. Mister Data,   prepare to disrupt the beam.   We're going to try to cut this   cord.
Meribor, this is your brother's   ceremony; now don't fidget.
We name this child for a dear   friend who died last year... but   who will now live on through his   namesake.
We name you -- Batai. In his   honor.
He's starting life in the warmth   of friends. Thank you.       Please, help yourselves to   something to eat.
It seems like just yesterday that   we had Meribor's naming ceremony.
I remember. I was so nervous I   thought I might drop her.       Now look at her... a little   lady...
She's no lady... tromping through   the hills with you all day,   digging those soil samples you   insist on collecting... she's   her father's daughter.
What is it?
I'd always thought I didn't need   children to make my life   complete... now, I can't imagine   life without them.
Kamin!
Get the doctor -- hurry!
I'm losing him!
I'm getting massive somatophysical   failure...
Two cc's delactovine...
Data, get that beam back.
There are severe fluctuations in   the isocortex... synaptic   responses are failing...
Begin full cardiac induction...
Blood pressure is dropping   rapidly... seventy over twenty   --
Data, you have to reestablish   that beam.
I am attempting to do so, Doctor.
Losing response in the isocortex   --
Cortical stimulator...
Start at ten percent...
Doctor, the beam is fully   restored.
Blood pressure up to ninety over   forty...       ... and rising...
Isocortical functions are   stabilizing... vital signs   approaching normal levels...
Meribor... ?
Happy day, father...
That's my hobby; find your own.
You're the one who taught me.   Don't complain if you turned me   into a scientist.
And what has the scientist been   up to today?
Analyzing soil samples.       There's not even any anerobic   bacteria. The soil is dead.

This isn't just a long drought,   is it?       I have entries in my log that go   back ten years. You have data   that precedes that by fifteen   years. You've reached the same   conclusion, I know you have.
I haven't reached any conclusion.   A good scientist doesn't function   by conjecture.
A good scientist functions by   hypothesizing and then proving   or disproving that hypothesis.   That's what I've done.
Tell me... why don't you spend   more time with that young fellow   Dannick?
You're changing the subject.
I'm not; I'm hypothesizing that   he's in love with you.
You've taught me to pursue the   truth -- no matter how painful   it might be. It's too late to   back off from that.
I've analyzed the rings in old   trees. I've examined rock strata   to correlate evidence of climactic   changes over the centuries.       Father -- this planet is dying.
Perhaps I should have filled your   head with trivial concerns...   games and toys and clothes...
I don't think you mean that.
No... but it saddens me to see   you bear the burden of knowing   things... things you can't change.
It's no more a burden than you   bear.
But I'm not sixteen. With my life   ahead of me.
Father? I think I should marry   Dannick sooner rather than   later... don't you?
I can only say...       ... Live now, Meribor. Always make   "now" the most precious time.   "Now" will not come again.
I love you, father.
Vital signs are holding... he's   been stable ever since the beam   was restored.       I don't know what more to do for   him.
Commander, we're starting to   receive telemetry from the probe   we launched.
Go ahead.
We've charted the alien probe's   radiation trail for just over   one light year.
Can you extrapolate a point of   origin?
Our best guess would be a star   system in the Silarian sector...   Kataan.
Kataan... I've never heard of it.   Data... ?
It is an unmapped system of six   planets.
Any of them inhabited?
Not any longer, sir. The star   went nova. All life in the   system was destroyed   approximately one thousand years   ago.
I put your shoes away for you   again.
Ah. Thank you, dear.
I've been looking through this   thing off and on for almost thirty   years... and I still can't see   what you and Meribor find so   fascinating.
Fine. Then maybe you'll sit down   and rest the way you're supposed   to.
(relinquishing the     telescope)   You treat me like some frail   flower. People have surgery all   the time.
He loves playing. And he's very   good at it, you know.
He loves doing a lot of things   -- too many. One week he wants   to be a botanist, the next week   a sculptor. I wish he could find   some focus in his life.
I think he has.
Maybe you should talk to him.
Batai?
Father... ?
I get the feeling from your mother   that you have something to tell   me.
Yes. I was waiting for the right   moment... but that won't ever   come.       I'm leaving school.
Leaving school -- ? No, you're   not --
I want to concentrate on my music.   It's what I care about.
Last year, all you cared about   was mathematics. A year before   that it was botany. Now --
But through it all there was my   music. I think you know that,   father...       This is the life I want.
We'll... we'll discuss it.
Thank you, father.
Even after all these years... you   have the ability to surprise me.
If music is what he wants... why   should I stand in his way?       Who knows how much time he'll   have to follow any dream.
Are you still planning to talk   to the Administrator tomorrow?
Yes.       It's possible he'll dismiss me   from the Council.
Unless, of course, you keep quiet.
The evidence is too pronounced.   I can't stay silent.
What a surprise.
Kamin, what do you hope to   accomplish? Spreading rumors that   the planet is doomed... there   could be chaos.
The facts are here. At least show   them to someone who will recognize   what they mean.
I won't be a party to your making   trouble --
If you won't take them, I most   certainly will.
Your observations... your   findings... our scientists reached   those same conclusions two years   ago.
Well, what did you expect us to   do? Make it public? Can you   imagine the effect... ?
Surely the technology exists to   save something of this world...   perhaps some people could be   evacuated...
Evacuated to where? Our   technology is limited. We're just   beginning to launch small   missiles...
A collection of genetic samples,   then -- something, anything --   you can't just let this   civilization die --
Enough!       There is a plan in the works. I   can't tell you more than that.
Father!
What is it -- ?
It's mother. Hurry.
Doctor -- ?
You see... I'll go to any   lengths... to get your attention.
You always had a flair for the   dramatic...
Doctor... Batai... leave us alone   for a moment. I want to talk to   my husband.
Did the Administrator look at your   evidence?
He didn't have to. They already   know.
So he didn't throw you off the   Council...
No...
Remember -- put your shoes away.
I will.
Doctor...
What is it?
I'm not sure. He's showing   physiological alterations... His   systemic readings are changing...
So are his respiratory functions.
Is he in danger?
I don't know... I don't understand   what's happening. The changes   are subtle, but...
... If I didn't know better, I'd   say these are the metabolic rates   of an eighty-year-old man.
Some children are certainly making   a lot of noise in here.
You shouldn't be out there for   so long. It's damaging, you know   that.
I'm wearing plenty of your skin   protector.
Mmnph.       Do you wear your skin protector   outdoors, young man?
Happy day, everybody! It's time   to go see the launching.
What "launching"? What's he   talking about?
They're sending up a missile,   father. We're going to watch it.
Are we, indeed. I'm not going   anywhere to watch anything.
Come on, Kamie; let's go see the   launching.
Breaks my heart to look at him...
Who?
My grandson. Breaks my heart...   he deserves a full rich life, and   he's not going to get one.
He's my child, and I tell you he   is getting one. I wish it could   be longer, but it's as full and   rich as we can possibly make   it.
Please come, father.
Why didn't I hear anything about   a launching?
Did everyone know about this   except me?
I can see all right from here.
You go on with the others. Go   hold onto my grandson, and watch   the damned thing go up... for all   the good it'll do. What is it   they're launching?
You know about it, father.   You've already seen it.
Seen it? What are you talking   about? I haven't seen any   missile.
Yes, you have, old friend...   Don't you remember?
Batai?
You saw it... just before you came   here.
We hoped our probe would encounter   someone in the future -- someone   who could be a teacher... who   could tell others about us.
A probe... that encounters   someone...
... someone in the future...       ... it's me, isn't it? I'm the   someone...
I'm the one it finds... that's   what this launching is -- a probe   that finds me... in the future...
Yes, my love...
Eline...
The rest of us have been gone for   a thousand years...
If you remember what we were, and   how we lived... then we'll have   found life again.
Eline...
Now we live. In you. Tell them   of us... my darling...
Something's happening...
The nucleonic beam has ceased,   Commander. The probe has shut   down.
His cerebral functions are   stabilizing.
Mister Worf, put a tractor beam   on the probe. I want it in   shuttlebay two for examination.
Yes, Commander.
What...
Please, Captain... don't get up   too quickly...
How long? How long have I been...   like this?
At least twenty, maybe twenty-five   minutes.
Twenty-five minutes?
Captain, I need you in sickbay   now. I want to run a full   diagnostic.
Very well, Doctor. But as soon   as you're done... I have a great   deal to tell you.
Come.
Hello, sir. Feeling better?
Yes, thank you... but I find I'm   having to remind myself that this   --       -- is really my home.
We were able to open the probe   and examine it. Whatever it was   that locked onto you must have   been self-terminating. It isn't   functional any longer.
We found this inside.
